He pushed his chair back and stood up.
I tried to hug him but he pushed me away.
She pushed her face towards him.
push something + adj. I pushed the door open.
He pushed me roughly out of the door.
She found a note pushed under the door.
He was deliberately pushed into the path of the vehicle.
Jack flung himself at Steve, but he simply pushed him away.
She leaned on the box and pushed it aside.
Protesters had been pushed violently to the ground.
They pushed the two desks together.
Ellie stood up, pushing her plate away.
I pushed the key into the lock.
The doctor pushed a needle into my arm.

senses.definition: to use force to move past somebody/something using your hands, arms, etc.
examples: People were pushing and shoving to get to the front.
push + adv./prep. The fans pushed against the barrier.
push your way + adv./prep. Try and push your way through the crowd.
A man pushed his way to the front of the crowd.
She pushed blindly past him and made for the door.
Please don't push in front of other customers.

senses.definition: to press a switch, button, etc., for example in order to make a machine start working
examples: I pushed the button for the top floor.
The operator must have accidentally pushed the switch on the joystick.
She pushed a lever and the machine responded.
Push the red button to open the doors.

senses.definition: to affect something so that it reaches a particular level or state
examples: This development could push the country into recession.
The rise in interest rates will push prices up.
Little pent-up demand exists to push the economy forward this year.
The surplus has helped push world prices to as little as 55 euros per tonne.
Such a huge population increase will continue to push food prices higher.
Rising inflation pushes down real interest rates.

senses.definition: to persuade or encourage somebody to do something that they may not want to do
examples: push somebody into something He made it clear that he would resist any attempt to push him into early retirement.
push somebody into doing something My teacher pushed me into entering the competition.
push somebody to do something No one pushed you to take the job, did they?
Her parents pushed her into accepting the job.
She claimed she had been pushed into posing for the photographs.

senses.definition: to make somebody work hard
examples: The music teacher really pushes her pupils.
Lucy should push herself a little harder.
He keeps pushing himself to get better.

senses.definition: to put pressure on somebody and make them angry or upset
examples: Her parents are very tolerant, but sometimes she pushes them too far.
He felt he was being pushed to the limit of his self-control.

senses.definition: to try hard to persuade people to accept or agree with a new idea, buy a new product, etc.
examples: The interview gave him a chance to push his latest movie.
She didn't want to push the point any further at that moment.
He continues to push his own political agenda.
Sales promotion is designed to push certain products.
The two governments are pushing for economic reform in the region.
They're pushing hard for a ban on GM foods.

senses.definition: to sell illegal drugs
to move forward quickly through an area
examples: The army pushed (on) towards the capital.

senses.definition: to be nearly 40, 50, etc. years old
to be dead and buried in the ground
to react in a sudden or extreme way to something unexpected that has frightened you
examples: The prime minister pressed the panic button yesterday as Britain’s economy plunged deeper into crisis.

senses.definition: to do exactly the right things to please somebody
examples: a new satirical comedy show that pushes all the right buttons

senses.definition: to spend a lot of money on enjoying yourself or celebrating something
to attempt to go beyond what is allowed or thought to be possible
examples: We aim to push the boundaries of what we can achieve.
She pushes her physical limits through various endurance challenges.

senses.definition: to go beyond the limits of what is allowed or thought to be possible
examples: He is a performer who consistently pushes the envelope of TV comedy.

senses.definition: to take a risk because you have successfully avoided problems in the past
examples: You didn't get caught last time, but don't push your luck!

senses.definition: to force somebody to lose control of their behaviour, usually after a particular event or series of events
examples: No one knows exactly what caused his breakdown, but losing his job may have pushed him over the edge.

senses.definition: to react in a sudden or extreme way to something unexpected that has frightened you
examples: The prime minister pushed the panic button yesterday as Britain's economy plunged deeper into crisis.

senses.definition: to try to forget about something unpleasant
examples: I tried to push the thought to the back of my mind.

senses.definition: to move something into a particular place or position
examples: Put the cases down there, please.
Did you put sugar in my coffee?
Put your hand up if you need more paper.

senses.definition: to move something into a particular place or position using force
examples: He put his fist through a glass door.

senses.definition: to cause somebody/something to go to a particular place
examples: Her family put her into a nursing home.
It was the year the Americans put a man on the moon.

senses.definition: to attach or fix something to something else
examples: We had to put new locks on all the doors.
We're not allowed to put posters on the walls.
Can you help me put the roof rack on the car?

senses.definition: to write something or make a mark on something
examples: Put your name here.
Friday at 11? I'll put it in my diary.
I couldn't read what she had put.

senses.definition: to bring somebody/something into the state or condition mentioned
examples: I was put in charge of the office.
The incident put her in a bad mood.
Put yourself in my position. What would you have done?
I tried to put the matter into perspective.
Don't go putting yourself at risk.
I am determined to put things right.
It was time to put their suggestion into practice.
This new injury will put him out of action for several weeks.
He put Ray on guard with a gun.

senses.definition: to make somebody/something feel something or be affected by something
examples: Her new job has put a great strain on her.
They put pressure on her to resign.
It's time you put a stop to this childish behaviour.

senses.definition: to express or state something in a particular way
examples: She put it very tactfully.
Put simply, we accept their offer or go bankrupt.
Simply put, the film is a masterpiece.
I was, to put it mildly, annoyed (= I was extremely angry).
Putting it bluntly, the project was a disaster.
He was too trusting—or, to put it another way, he had no head for business.
The meat was—how shall I put it?—a little overdone.
As T.S. Eliot puts it…
She had never tried to put this feeling into words.
Can you help me put this letter into good English, please?
I thought you put your points very well.

senses.definition: to give or attach a particular level of importance, trust, value, etc. to something
examples: Our company puts the emphasis on quality.
He put a limit on the amount we could spend.

senses.definition: to consider somebody/something to belong to the class or level mentioned
examples: I'd put her in the top rank of modern novelists.

senses.definition: to throw the shot
used to say that you think somebody is capable of doing something wrong, illegal, etc.
to have many sexual partners
to suggest something to somebody to see if they can argue against it
examples: I put it to you that you are the only person who had a motive for the crime.

senses.definition: to persuade somebody to believe something that is not true
examples: Don't try to put one over on me!

senses.definition: to force somebody to experience something difficult or unpleasant
examples: They really put me through it (= asked me difficult questions) at the interview.

senses.definition: used when comparing or contrasting somebody/something with a group of other people or things to mean ‘combined’ or ‘in total’
examples: Your department spent more last year than all the others put together.

senses.definition: used to tell somebody to stop just talking about something and actually do it, show it, etc.
